title: The Stock Market Doesn’t Care About the Trump Whistleblower Complaint — Or Impeachment For That Matter
text:
Text size

Thursday was a day of political theater with the release of the whistleblower report alleging President Donald Trump threatened Ukraine to get it to investigate Joe Biden, the Democratic presidential front-runner. The stock market didn’t care.

The complaint alleged that Trump tried to threaten Ukraine’s president to investigate Biden and his son. Trump denied the allegations and said he applied “no pressure.” It was also alleged that a transcript of the call was moved off one computer network and onto another.



The market once again shrugged off the political drama. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 76.26 points, or 0.3%, to 26,894.45 on Thursday, after being down well more than 100 points. The S&P 500 dipped 0.2% to 2977.77, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.6% to 8030.66.

And it wasn’t just Thursday. The S&P 500 has dipped 0.5% so far this week, while the Dow is 0.1% despite the launch of an impeachment inquiry against the president. It is likely investors will continue not to care.

Part of that is history: During the impeachments of Richard Nixon and Bill Clinton the market simply continued to follow the trend it was already on. Also, the odds that Trump will be removed from office are tiny. Even if the House votes to impeach—still no sure thing—two-thirds of the Senate would have to vote for Trump’s removal. That’s highly unlikely given the fact that the Senate is controlled by the Republicans, the president's party.

In fact, the market seems to be worrying more about China and the state of the U.S. economy than impeachment, according to Sevens Report’s Tom Essaye.

“U.S./China trade remains the singular most important issue facing this market, and as long as markets have ‘hope’ of a U.S./China trade ‘truce,’ it’ll be hard to sustain any material downside in stocks,” he writes. “[That] ‘hope’ is based on the idea that a lasting U.S./China trade truce (so different than the past two we’ve had) will reduce pressure on the U.S. and global manufacturing sectors, and combined with coordinated global easing (so rate cuts from the ECB/PBOC/Fed) will cause a 2016 style reflation, and an extension of the economic expansion...if we ignore hope for a second and look at the facts, it remains difficult to see how a trade truce revives the global manufacturing sector.”

And impeachment? “[The] impeachment drama, which will certainly continue to dominate the headlines, likely won’t impact markets in the near or medium term unless there is a big surprise lurking,” Essaye writes.

And maybe not even then.

Write to Ben Levisohn at Ben.Levisohn@barrons.com
description: The market is once again shrugging off the political drama, as investors stay focused on things like China trade and the U.S. economy.
